content.description:
Mobile/Multi-access edge computing (MEC) is one key technology to achieve low-latency performance in cellular networks. It has been determined as a key feature in future 5G networks by both ETSI and 3GPP standardization organizations. It seeks to provide a cloud computing platform at the network edge to be closer to mobile users than conventional cloud systems. Due to emerging low-latency demands, several MEC deployment solutions are being in development. We seek to design a MEC platform that can be easily deployed in 4G LTE networks, as well as may be used as a reference design for future 5G networks.

In this project, I focused on the integration between Kubernetes and MEC platform, allowing end-users to define their custom domain name for a specific DNS provider. To be more specific, I first I containerized the MEC kernel module (involving GPRS Tunnelling Protocol module and forwarding module), making network administrator easier to deploy the MEC kernel as either a Docker container or Helm Chart to their environment. Secondly, I established the experiment environment with three machines acting as LTE EPC (Evolved Packet Core), UE(User Equipment), and MEC in 4G LTE, which involves NextEPC installation and configuration, packet routing using iptables and arp, and microk8s installation and configuration. On top of that, I packaged layer-4 and layer-7 load balancing to the MEC platform with External-DNS, enabling end-users to use annotation declaration to configure external DNS servers (AWS Route53, Google CloudDNS, and others) for Kubernetes Ingresses and Services. Finally, I experimented with many features provided by the Rancher, the open-source multi-cluster orchestration platform, including continuous integration and delivery, health and readiness probe, basic operation and configuration on a service and ingress in the Kubernetes.
